post.author: Mike
post.title: How to save miles when redeeming award tickets?
post.content:
There was a time when only frequent flyers were fortunate enough to book flights with airline miles. Times have changed and now every passenger who steps on a commercial air craft can now reap rewards.

The purchase of most airline tickets is usually accompanied by an enticement to join the carrier's loyalty scheme and book flights with airline miles. Most airlines are part of one airline alliance or other to help the traveling public acquire loyalty miles. 

There are a number of ways to book flights with airline miles.

  • Every time a passenger flies with an allied airline, a certain number of air miles are awarded for both inbound and outbound flights. Longer flights accumulate larger numbers of miles.
  • Hotel priority club awards may also permit club members to book flights with airline miles.
  • Some banks operate reward schemes through which individuals may book flights. Credit card companies also offer reward points that can be changed into air miles. It is perfectly legitimate to Book flights with airline miles through a bank account website and paying for a credit card  is an excellent way to save money on three separate fronts.

It is worth signing up for every one of these, even though many frequent flyers are passionately loyalty to their favorite carrier. The family favorite airline will not always fly to every destination. The carrier you end up on may belong to the same loyalty scheme as the one with the fluffy blankets and the cool duty frees.

There are three main alliances that enable passengers to book flights with airline miles:

  • Sky Team
  • One World
  • Star Alliance

The list of passenger airlines that allow passengers to book flights with airline miles through an alliance may found on the Elite TravelGuru website. Even occasional travelers who only fly once every other year may find that they accumulate meaningful reward points that come in handy when least expected. Huge discounts on minor upgrades from economy to premium economy class are often advertised at the airport on the date of departure.

Passengers who take advantage of these cheap deals for the extra leg room and leather seats may find themselves upgraded all the way to first class. If the premium economy class has only one or two passengers, it's not worth the airline's trouble to keep a separate seating section open. It is easier for the cabin staff to just bump the passengers up. Unfortunately, the upgrade does not apply to the loyalty miles accumulated on that flight; the original ticket purchase determines the number of miles earned.
